questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5'-3' Exonuclease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase I lacks the 5'-3' exonuclease activity but retains the 5'->3' polymerase and 3'-5' exonuclease (proofreading) activities, making it useful for DNA synthesis and recombinant DNA technology.

questions.text: In urea cycle disorders, which of the following can be used to reduce the levels of ammonia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phenylbutyrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phenylbutyrate is used in urea cycle disorders to reduce ammonia levels by converting ammonia into phenylacetylglutamine, which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Match the following with the respective ages of fusion: ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The age of fusion are:

questions.text: 5 Fluoro-Uracil causes thymineless cell death after getting converted to a product. Here the inhibition is of which enzyme: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thymidylate synthase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 5-Florouracil (5-FU) is a chemotherapeutic agent that is converted into various active metabolites inside the cell. One of its major active metabolites, 2-deoxy 5-fluoro uridylic acid (FdUMP), inhibits thymidylate synthase. Thymidylate synthase is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in the synthesis of thymidine, a nucleotide required for DNA replication.
  • ➤ Inhibition of thymidylate synthase leads to a decrease in the production of thymidine, which is essential for DNA synthesis. Thymineless cell death occurs when there is a deficiency of thymidine, affecting DNA replication and leading to cell death.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 711
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 711

questions.text: In a village, the residents find a new groundwater source. After intake of water from this source many villagers presented with nausea, vomiting, dark bloody stools, conjunctivitis, and a burning sensation in the throat and stomach. Which poisoning do you suspect in this case? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Arsenic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: In arterial blood gas analysis which one of the following is derived or calculated? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bicarbonate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis, we measure specific parameters directly from the arterial blood sample. The directly measured values include:
  • • pH : The measure of hydrogen ion concentration, indicating the acidity or alkalinity of the blood. pCO2 : The partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood, indicating how well CO2 is being eliminated from the body. pO2 : The partial pressure of oxygen in the blood, indicating how well oxygen is being absorbed from the lungs.
  • • pH : The measure of hydrogen ion concentration, indicating the acidity or alkalinity of the blood.
  • • pH
  • • pCO2 : The partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood, indicating how well CO2 is being eliminated from the body.
  • • pCO2
  • • pO2 : The partial pressure of oxygen in the blood, indicating how well oxygen is being absorbed from the lungs.
  • • pO2
  • • Bicarbonate (HCO3-) , however, is not directly measured in ABG analysis. Instead, it is derived from the measured values using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation or calculated from the blood gas analyzer. Along with bicarbonate, base excess or base deficit values are also derived to assess the metabolic component of the acid-base balance.
  • • Bicarbonate (HCO3-)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. pH : This is a measured value that indicates the hydrogen ion concentration in the blood.
  • • Option A. pH
  • • Option B. pCO2 : This is a measured value representing the partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood.
  • • Option B. pCO2
  • • Option C. pO2 : This is a measured value representing the partial pressure of oxygen in the blood.
  • • Option C. pO2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In arterial blood gas analysis, bicarbonate is a derived or calculated value, whereas pH, pCO2, and pO2 are directly measured parameters.

questions.text: Antidote for Benzodiazepine poisoning?(FMGE 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Flumazenil

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Benzodiazepine poisoning is characterized by symptoms such as drowsiness, confusion, dizziness, blurred vision, weakness, slurred speech, lack of coordination, difficulty breathing, and in severe cases, coma. The antidote for benzodiazepine poisoning is Flumazenil. It acts by competitively inhibiting the benzodiazepine binding site on the GABA receptor. When administered intravenously, it rapidly reverses the sedative effects of benzodiazepines.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Naloxone: Incorrect because naloxone is the antidote for opioid poisoning.
  • • Option B. Naloxone:
  • • Option C. Atropine: Incorrect as atropine is used for anticholinergic poisoning and organophosphate poisoning.
  • • Option C. Atropine:
  • • Option D. Physostigmine: Incorrect because physostigmine is used for anticholinergic toxicity.
  • • Option D. Physostigmine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Key points to understand about benzodiazepine poisoning and its antidote:
  • ➤ Key points to understand about benzodiazepine poisoning and its antidote:

Ans. A) Most abundant AA is Phenyl-alanine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the injury in the image below: ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Abrasion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Abrasions are superficial injuries involving only the epidermis, with no bleeding and no scar formation, and are typically simple hurts except for corneal abrasions.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not formed after post-translational modification? ( AIIMS May 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Selenocysteine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: You see these marks on the forearm of a woman who is being constantly harassed for dowry by her in-laws. What is this finding known as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hesitation cuts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hesitation cuts are superficial, parallel, and multiple cuts typically found in accessible areas like the wrist or throat, often indicating a cry for help or a practice attempt by individuals contemplating suicide.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes simultaneously incorporates molecular oxygen and produces water? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cytochrome C oxidase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Cytochrome C oxidase (COX) is present in the complex IV of ETC. COX accepts electrons from cytochrome c and uses them to reduce molecular oxygen to water, releasing energy in the process.
  • • Cytochrome C oxidase (COX)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Catalase on the other hand is an oxidoreductase which is involved in the conversion of hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen.
  • • Option A. Catalase
  • • Option C. Acetyl CoA Carboxylase is the Rate limiting enzyme of fatty acid synthesis and is also called Malonyl CoA Synthetase.
  • • Option C. Acetyl CoA Carboxylase
  • • Option D. Cholinesterase (ChE) is a type of enzyme that breaks down the neurotransmitter acetylcholine in the body. Inhibitors of cholinesterase activity are used therapeutically in the treatment of a variety of conditions, including Alzheimer's disease, myasthenia gravis, and glaucoma.
  • • Option D. Cholinesterase (ChE)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Defects in COX activity has been linked to a number of human diseases, including Leigh syndrome, a rare neurological disorder, and some forms of muscular dystrophy. Additionally, COX has been shown to play a role in aging and age-related diseases, such as Alzheimer's disease.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 116
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 116

questions.text: If any unsound minded person commits any crime unconsciously it won't be considered as a punishable offence. This is defined by which of the following law? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mc Naughten's rule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ McNaughten's rule provides the legal framework for the insanity defense, asserting that an individual who commits a crime while being incapable of understanding the nature or wrongfulness of their actions due to unsoundness of mind cannot be held criminally responsible.

questions.text: In a gunshot case, blackening is noted surrounding a firearm entry wound. Blackening occurs mainly due to: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  D. Black smoke particles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The presence of blackening, soot, and unburnt gunpowder at a gunshot entry wound provides crucial information about the distance and angle of the shot.

questions.explanation:

questions.text: The first organ to undergo Rigor mortis amongst the following options is: ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Myocardium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to Nysten's law, rigor mortis first affects the myocardium (heart muscle) among the listed options.
  • ➤ Rigor mortis follows the “rule of 12”- 12 hrs. to set in, remains for 12 hrs., and passes off in 12 hrs.

questions.text: A person consumed 2 bottles of alcohol purchased from a local shop and presented to the emergency department with blurring of vision, nausea, confusion, and hypotension. What should be given for the treatment? (FMGE 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ethyl alcohol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Blurring of vision, along with other symptoms such as nausea, confusion, and hypotension, suggests methyl alcohol (methanol) poisoning. Methyl alcohol is toxic because its metabolism produces formic acid, which is particularly harmful to the eyes and can cause blindness.
  • • Key points to understand about methyl alcohol poisoning and its treatment:
  • • Key points to understand about methyl alcohol poisoning and its treatment:
  • • Methyl Alcohol (Methanol) Poisoning: Methanol is often used to adulterate ethyl alcohol (ethanol) in locally produced alcoholic beverages because it is cheaper and has similar initial effects. Methanol metabolism produces formic acid, which is toxic, particularly to the eyes, causing symptoms like blurring of vision. Treatment of Methanol Poisoning: Ethyl Alcohol (Ethanol): Ethanol is used as an antidote for methanol poisoning because it competes with methanol for alcohol dehydrogenase, the enzyme responsible for metabolizing both alcohols. By competing for this enzyme, ethanol prevents the formation of toxic metabolites from methanol. Fomepizole (4-Methylpyrazole): Another antidote that inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase and prevents the formation of toxic metabolites. Sodium Bicarbonate: Used to correct metabolic acidosis. Dialysis: Used in severe cases to remove methanol and formic acid from the blood.
  • • Methyl Alcohol (Methanol) Poisoning: Methanol is often used to adulterate ethyl alcohol (ethanol) in locally produced alcoholic beverages because it is cheaper and has similar initial effects. Methanol metabolism produces formic acid, which is toxic, particularly to the eyes, causing symptoms like blurring of vision.
  • • Methyl Alcohol (Methanol) Poisoning:
  • • Methanol is often used to adulterate ethyl alcohol (ethanol) in locally produced alcoholic beverages because it is cheaper and has similar initial effects. Methanol metabolism produces formic acid, which is toxic, particularly to the eyes, causing symptoms like blurring of vision.
  • • Methanol is often used to adulterate ethyl alcohol (ethanol) in locally produced alcoholic beverages because it is cheaper and has similar initial effects.
  • • adulterate
  • • Methanol metabolism produces formic acid, which is toxic, particularly to the eyes, causing symptoms like blurring of vision.
  • • Treatment of Methanol Poisoning: Ethyl Alcohol (Ethanol): Ethanol is used as an antidote for methanol poisoning because it competes with methanol for alcohol dehydrogenase, the enzyme responsible for metabolizing both alcohols. By competing for this enzyme, ethanol prevents the formation of toxic metabolites from methanol. Fomepizole (4-Methylpyrazole): Another antidote that inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase and prevents the formation of toxic metabolites. Sodium Bicarbonate: Used to correct metabolic acidosis. Dialysis: Used in severe cases to remove methanol and formic acid from the blood.
  • • Treatment of Methanol Poisoning:
  • • Ethyl Alcohol (Ethanol): Ethanol is used as an antidote for methanol poisoning because it competes with methanol for alcohol dehydrogenase, the enzyme responsible for metabolizing both alcohols. By competing for this enzyme, ethanol prevents the formation of toxic metabolites from methanol. Fomepizole (4-Methylpyrazole): Another antidote that inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase and prevents the formation of toxic metabolites. Sodium Bicarbonate: Used to correct metabolic acidosis. Dialysis: Used in severe cases to remove methanol and formic acid from the blood.
  • • Ethyl Alcohol (Ethanol): Ethanol is used as an antidote for methanol poisoning because it competes with methanol for alcohol dehydrogenase, the enzyme responsible for metabolizing both alcohols. By competing for this enzyme, ethanol prevents the formation of toxic metabolites from methanol.
  • • Ethyl Alcohol (Ethanol):
  • • Fomepizole (4-Methylpyrazole): Another antidote that inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase and prevents the formation of toxic metabolites.
  • • Fomepizole (4-Methylpyrazole):
  • • Sodium Bicarbonate: Used to correct metabolic acidosis.
  • • Sodium Bicarbonate:
  • • Dialysis: Used in severe cases to remove methanol and formic acid from the blood.
  • • Dialysis:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Flumazenil: Incorrect because flumazenil is the antidote for benzodiazepine poisoning.
  • • Option A. Flumazenil:
  • • Option C. Atropine: Incorrect as atropine is used for organophosphate and other cholinergic poisonings.
  • • Option C. Atropine:
  • • Option D. Naloxone: Incorrect because naloxone is the antidote for opioid poisoning.
  • • Option D. Naloxone:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blurring of vision, nausea, confusion, and hypotension in the context of alcohol consumption from a local shop strongly suggest methanol poisoning. The appropriate treatment is ethyl alcohol, which competes with methanol for metabolism and prevents the formation of toxic metabolites.
  • ➤ Table for Treatment of Methanol and Ethylene Glycol Poisoning
  • ➤ Table for Treatment of Methanol and Ethylene Glycol Poisoning

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who is a chronic alcoholic was presented with complaints of confusion, tingling sensation. His history revealed polished rice is his main diet. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Beriberi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic alcoholism and a diet primarily consisting of polished rice can lead to thiamine deficiency, resulting in Beriberi, which can manifest as either dry (neurological symptoms) or wet (cardiac symptoms) Beriberi.

questions.text: DNA-Protein interactions can be studied by using: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) DNA footprinting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DNA footprinting is the appropriate method for studying DNA-Protein interactions, as it allows researchers to identify the specific binding sites of proteins on DNA by selectively cleaving or modifying the DNA sequence. This technique is fundamental for understanding how proteins interact with DNA in various biological processes.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 451

questions.text: What is Edmond Locard known for? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Theory of exchange

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Edmond Locard is best known for Locard's Exchange Principle, which states that whenever two bodies come into contact, there is an exchange of materials, thereby linking criminals to crime scenes.

questions.text: Binding site of miRNA on mRNA?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3’ UTR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The binding site of miRNA on mRNA is typically the 3’ UTR (Untranslated Region), where miRNA can regulate gene expression by binding and influencing mRNA stability or translation.
  • ➤ Ref - Lehninger 6 th e/p 1081
  • ➤ Ref - Lehninger 6 th e/p 1081

questions.text: The catalytic efficiency of enzyme is best expressed by which of the following kinetic constants? ( AIIMS May 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Kcat/Km

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The catalytic efficiency of an enzyme is best expressed by the ratio Kcat/Km, as it provides a measure of how effectively the enzyme converts substrate into product, considering both the enzyme's turnover rate and its substrate affinity.

questions.text: A breastfed infant presents with angular stomatitis, cheilosis, and a magenta-colored tongue. The mother is on a strict vegan diet without supplements. Physical examination reveals seborrheic dermatitis around the nasolabial folds and ears. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Riboflavin deficiency

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency is the correct answer. The clinical presentation shows classic signs:
  • • Angular stomatitis and cheilosis Magenta-colored tongue Seborrheic dermatitis in characteristic locations Common in strict vegans without supplementation Can affect breastfed infants of deficient mothers
  • • Angular stomatitis and cheilosis
  • • Magenta-colored tongue
  • • Seborrheic dermatitis in characteristic locations
  • • Common in strict vegans without supplementation
  • • Can affect breastfed infants of deficient mothers
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency: While common in vegans, B12 deficiency primarily presents with megaloblastic anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and developmental delay in infants. Mucocutaneous symptoms are not prominent.
  • • Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency:
  • • Option C. Niacin deficiency: Pellagra presents with the classic triad of dermatitis (including Casal's necklace), diarrhea, and dementia. The magenta tongue and seborrheic pattern are not characteristic.
  • • Option C. Niacin deficiency:
  • • Option D. Vitamin C deficiency: Scurvy presents with bleeding gums, perifollicular hemorrhages, and poor wound healing, not the mucocutaneous symptoms described.
  • • Option D. Vitamin C deficiency:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand:
  • ➤ 1. Riboflavin deficiency manifestations:
  • ➤ Angular stomatitis Cheilosis Magenta tongue Seborrheic dermatitis
  • ➤ Angular stomatitis
  • ➤ Cheilosis
  • ➤ Magenta tongue
  • ➤ Seborrheic dermatitis
  • ➤ 2. Risk factors:
  • ➤ Vegan diet without supplementation Maternal deficiency affecting breastfed infants
  • ➤ Vegan diet without supplementation
  • ➤ Maternal deficiency affecting breastfed infants
  • ➤ 3. Differential B-vitamin deficiencies:
  • ➤ B2: Predominant mucocutaneous symptoms B3: Pellagra triad B12: Hematologic and neurologic symptoms
  • ➤ B2: Predominant mucocutaneous symptoms
  • ➤ B3: Pellagra triad
  • ➤ B12: Hematologic and neurologic symptoms
  • ➤ 4. Importance of maternal supplementation during breastfeeding

questions.text: Which of the following compound(s) is most likely to cause diabetic cataract:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Accumulation of sorbitol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In diabetes, high levels of glucose in the lens of the eye can lead to increased production of sorbitol via the aldose reductase pathway. Sorbitol, being osmotically active, cannot easily cross cell membranes and thus accumulates in the lens, leading to an osmotic imbalance that causes swelling, opacification, and eventually, cataract formation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B . Accumulation of Galactose + Glucose: While accumulation of galactose can lead to cataract formation (as seen in classic galactosemia), in the context of diabetes, the primary issue is the accumulation of sorbitol derived from glucose. Galactose is not typically elevated in diabetic patients unless there is a concurrent metabolic disorder affecting galactose metabolism.
  • • Option B
  • • Accumulation of Galactose + Glucose:
  • • Option C . Accumulation of Galactitol + Glucose: Similar to option B, while galactitol (formed from galactose) can contribute to cataract formation in conditions like galactosemia, it is not the primary concern in diabetic cataract where the key issue is sorbitol accumulation from glucose.
  • • Option C
  • • Accumulation of Galactitol + Glucose:
  • • Option D . Accumulation of Glucose Only: While hyperglycemia (high glucose levels) is the underlying cause of diabetic complications, including cataracts, it's the metabolic conversion of this excess glucose to sorbitol in the lens that primarily contributes to cataract formation, not the accumulation of glucose alone.
  • • Option D
  • • Accumulation of Glucose Only:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Diabetes mellitus, in the lens by polyol pathway, glucose converted to sorbitol by the enzyme Aldose reductase. Excess Glucose can enter the lens of the eye and get converted to Sorbitol with the help of aldose reductase. This enzyme is a major contributor to diabetic complication due to accumulation of sorbitol which is hygroscopic sugar and causes swelling of the eye in untreated diabetic patients In galactosemia, Dulcitol or Galactitol is responsible for cataract.
  • ➤ In Diabetes mellitus, in the lens by polyol pathway, glucose converted to sorbitol by the enzyme Aldose reductase. Excess Glucose can enter the lens of the eye and get converted to Sorbitol with the help of aldose reductase. This enzyme is a major contributor to diabetic complication due to accumulation of sorbitol which is hygroscopic sugar and causes swelling of the eye in untreated diabetic patients
  • ➤ sorbitol
  • ➤ In galactosemia, Dulcitol or Galactitol is responsible for cataract.
  • ➤ Dulcitol or Galactitol
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 200
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 200

questions.text: Which of the below agents cause hypertension when consumed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Cocaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug and has stimulant effects on CNS and cardiovascular system as mentioned below:
  • ➤ Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug and has stimulant effects on CNS and cardiovascular system as mentioned below:
  • ➤ Agitation and Restlessness Tachycardia / Palpitations Hypertension Dilated Pupils Profuse Sweating Hyperthermia Restlessness Paranoia and hallucinations. Serious Cardiovascular Effects: Arrhythmias, Myocardial Infarction Respiratory Distress: Rapid, shallow breathing and respiratory distress. Seizures, Confusion and Altered Mental Status
  • ➤ Agitation and Restlessness
  • ➤ Tachycardia / Palpitations
  • ➤ Hypertension
  • ➤ Dilated Pupils
  • ➤ Profuse Sweating
  • ➤ Hyperthermia
  • ➤ Restlessness
  • ➤ Paranoia and hallucinations.
  • ➤ Serious Cardiovascular Effects: Arrhythmias, Myocardial Infarction
  • ➤ Respiratory Distress: Rapid, shallow breathing and respiratory distress.
  • ➤ Seizures, Confusion and Altered Mental Status

questions.text: A mentally challenged female requires consent for MTP. The consent can be given to her by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Legal guardian

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the case of a mentally challenged female requiring consent for Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP), the consent must be given by her legal guardian.
  • • According to Indian law, consent from a guardian is required in two situations:
  • • If the person seeking MTP is below 18 years of age. If the person seeking MTP is mentally challenged.
  • • If the person seeking MTP is below 18 years of age.
  • • If the person seeking MTP is mentally challenged.
  • • In other cases, the consent of a guardian is not mandatory.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option. A. Husband/Partner: While it is advisable to obtain consent from the husband or partner to avoid potential divorce proceedings, it is not a legal requirement for MTP.
  • • Option. A. Husband/Partner:
  • • Option. C. Herself: A mentally challenged female is not considered capable of giving informed consent for MTP.
  • • Option. C. Herself:
  • • Option. D. Magistrate: A magistrate's consent is not required for MTP in the case of a mentally challenged female.
  • • Option. D. Magistrate:
  • • Additional information:
  • • Additional information:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In the case of a mentally challenged female requiring consent for MTP, the consent must be provided by her legal guardian, as she is not considered capable of giving informed consent herself.

questions.text: A patient presents with depression, anxiety, and insomnia. Laboratory analysis reveals decreased levels of a neurotransmitter derived from an essential amino acid. Which amino acid is the precursor for this neurotransmitter involved in sleep-wake cycle regulation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tryptophan

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tryptophan is the correct answer. It is the essential amino acid precursor for:
  • • Serotonin (5-HT), a key neurotransmitter for mood regulation Melatonin, which regulates sleep-wake cycles This pathway explains the patient's symptoms of depression, anxiety, and sleep disturbances.
  • • Serotonin (5-HT), a key neurotransmitter for mood regulation
  • • Melatonin, which regulates sleep-wake cycles This pathway explains the patient's symptoms of depression, anxiety, and sleep disturbances.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Glutamine: While involved in neurotransmitter metabolism, glutamine is not directly involved in serotonin or melatonin synthesis. It's primarily involved in glutamate/GABA metabolism.
  • • Option A. Glutamine:
  • • Option B. Glycine: Although glycine is an inhibitory neurotransmitter and important for heme synthesis, it's not involved in serotonin/melatonin pathway or sleep-wake cycle regulation.
  • • Option B. Glycine:
  • • Option D. Valine: As a branched-chain amino acid, valine is important for protein synthesis and energy metabolism but doesn't contribute to neurotransmitter synthesis.
  • • Option D. Valine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand key amino acid derivatives:
  • ➤ 1. Tryptophan pathway:
  • ➤ Serotonin synthesis Melatonin production NAD+ synthesis (niacin)
  • ➤ Serotonin synthesis
  • ➤ Melatonin production
  • ➤ NAD+ synthesis (niacin)
  • ➤ 2. Clinical significance:
  • ➤ Mood regulation Sleep-wake cycle Depression/anxiety pathophysiology
  • ➤ Mood regulation
  • ➤ Sleep-wake cycle
  • ➤ Depression/anxiety pathophysiology
  • ➤ 3. Other important amino acid products:
  • ➤ Tyrosine → catecholamines, thyroid hormones Histidine → histamine Glycine → heme, glutathione Arginine → nitric oxide
  • ➤ Tyrosine → catecholamines, thyroid hormones
  • ➤ Histidine → histamine
  • ➤ Glycine → heme, glutathione
  • ➤ Arginine → nitric oxide

questions.text: The WHO-created slogan 'Perform Correctly,' regarding initial snake bite assistance, includes everything listed below except for which one? ( INICET May 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Incisions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Do not interfere with the snake bite wound. Always reassure the patient, immobilize the limb, and seek medical help immediately without attempting harmful interventions like making incisions or applying chemicals.

questions.text: After visiting a village temple with his grandmother, a 5-year-old boy began crying intensely during the return trip. Within three hours, he was brought to the emergency department. He displayed symptoms such as altered consciousness, cold and sweaty extremities, heightened salivation, and excessive sweating. Physical examination revealed paleness and priapism, along with vital signs as follows: blood pressure of 140/78 mmHg, heart rate of 152 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Considering his condition, what treatment approach would you choose for his management? ( INICET May 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Prazosin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prazosin is the first-line treatment for scorpion envenomation due to its ability to suppress sympathetic outflow and mitigate the effects of the autonomic storm.
  • ➤ Prazosin

questions.text: Which of the following is false in a patient with advanced liver disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate is increased.

options.label: B
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate from alpha-ketoglutarate

questions.correct_answer: A. Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate is increased.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Detoxification of ammonia takes place in the liver, where it is metabolised and excreted as urea (urea cycle). Due to impairment of ammonia metabolism in advanced liver disease, ammonia levels increase which withdraws α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate and glutamine.
  • ➤ This in turn results in lowered concentrations of all citric acid cycle intermediates, and hence decreased ATP synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following can alter the gene expression by methylation and acetylation but not change the gene sequence? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Epigenetics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epigenetics involves modifications such as methylation and acetylation that regulate gene expression without changing the DNA sequence, playing a crucial role in various biological processes and diseases.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes this?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Niacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Niacin is another B-vitamin that is essential for various bodily functions. It plays a role in converting nutrients into energy, creating cholesterol and fats, repairing DNA, and acting as an antioxidant. Niacin is important for overall metabolic health. Severe niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which can have serious effects on the skin, digestive system, and nervous system.
  • ➤ Niacin deficiency can be caused by:
  • ➤ Dietary deficiency of tryptophan Dietary deficiency Vitamin B2 and B6 deficiency Carcinoid syndrome Hartnup’s disease
  • ➤ Dietary deficiency of tryptophan
  • ➤ Dietary deficiency Vitamin B2 and B6 deficiency
  • ➤ Carcinoid syndrome
  • ➤ Hartnup’s disease
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 534-535
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 534-535

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent) Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

questions.text: A surgeon returns home from a party after many pegs of alcohol and was called to perform an emergency operation. During the operation, the assisting staff noticed the surgeon’s hand shaking and instruments falling. He eventually nicks an artery and the patient collapses. Under which of the following terms will this incident be tried? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Criminal negligence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Performing an operation while under the influence of alcohol and causing harm to a patient constitutes criminal negligence, which is tried in a criminal court and can result in imprisonment and fines.

questions.text: Identify the enzyme from the following list that is classified as a "Suicide Enzyme." (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cyclooxygenase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cyclooxygenase is classified as a suicide enzyme because it can be irreversibly inhibited by aspirin through a mechanism-based inhibition process. In suicide inhibition, the enzyme itself participates in converting the inhibitor into a highly reactive form that permanently binds to and inactivates the enzyme. Aspirin acts as a suicide inhibitor of cyclooxygenase by covalently modifying a specific serine residue in the enzyme's active site through acetylation, which prevents access of the substrate to the catalytic site and results in permanent inactivation of the enzyme.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Lipoxygenase: While this enzyme also participates in the arachidonic acid pathway, it is not characterized as undergoing suicide inhibition by its substrates or known inhibitors.
  • • Option B. Lipoxygenase:
  • • Option C. Pyruvate Dehydrogenase: is regulated by phosphorylation and product inhibition, but it does not undergo suicide inactivation.
  • • Option C. Pyruvate Dehydrogenase:
  • • Option D. Thromboxane Synthase: This enzyme participates in the prostaglandin synthesis pathway but is not known to undergo suicide inhibition.
  • • Option D. Thromboxane Synthase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Suicide inhibition involves the enzyme converting a substrate analog into a reactive species that irreversibly inhibits the enzyme itself—cyclooxygenase exemplifies this mechanism where aspirin covalently modifies the enzyme, permanently inactivating it.

questions.text: True about Warburg effect?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.correct_answer: B. Aerobic glycolysis with lactate formation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aerobic glycolysis with lactate formation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Warburg effect
  • ➤ Warburg effect
  • ➤ This effect occurs in cancerous cells. This is a paradox from normal in the sense that Cancer cells convert pyruvate to lactate even in the presence of O 2 . This is known as aerobic glycolysis. Energy derived from conversion of pyruvate to lactate is just 2 ATPs , hence rapidly growing cancer cells take up large amount of glucose compared to normal cells. Due to large amount of glucose used, patients have Cachexia (weight loss).
  • ➤ This effect occurs in cancerous cells. This is a paradox from normal in the sense that Cancer cells convert pyruvate to lactate even in the presence of O 2 . This is known as aerobic glycolysis.
  • ➤ aerobic glycolysis.
  • ➤ Energy derived from conversion of pyruvate to lactate is just 2 ATPs , hence rapidly growing cancer cells take up large amount of glucose compared to normal cells. Due to large amount of glucose used, patients have Cachexia (weight loss).
  • ➤ 2 ATPs

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 30th ed/pg- 738

questions.text: A 40-year-old female consumed a white colored rodenticide powder and presents with a potassium level of 2.5 mEq/L. She has irregular pulse and muscle paralysis. ECG shows multiple ventricular ectopic beats. What is the suspected poison? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Barium Carbonate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypokalemia with symptoms such as muscle paralysis, irregular pulse, and ECG changes like ventricular ectopic beats strongly suggest poisoning with barium carbonate.

questions.text: Which of the following minerals has the highest daily requirement? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Calcium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Calcium is classified as a macromineral because the body requires it in large amounts (>100 mg/day). Adults need approximately 1000-1200 mg of calcium daily for maintaining bone health, muscle function, nerve transmission, and blood clotting. This requirement is significantly higher than other minerals.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Iodine: Iodine is a micronutrient/trace mineral with a much lower daily requirement (150 mcg/day for adults). Though essential for thyroid hormone synthesis, the required amount is much smaller than calcium.
  • • Option A. Iodine:
  • • Option C. Zinc: Zinc is a micronutrient with recommended daily intake of 8-11 mg/day. While crucial for immune function and enzyme activity, its requirement is far less than calcium.
  • • Option C. Zinc:
  • • Option D. Iron: Iron, though essential for hemoglobin formation, is needed in relatively small amounts (8-18 mg/day depending on age and gender). This is significantly less than the daily calcium requirement.
  • • Option D. Iron:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the classification of minerals based on daily requirements:
  • ➤ Macrominerals (>100 mg/day): Calcium, Phosphorus, Magnesium, Sodium, Potassium, Chloride Microminerals/Trace minerals (<100 mg/day): Iron, Zinc, Copper, Iodine, Selenium, Chromium, etc.
  • ➤ Macrominerals (>100 mg/day): Calcium, Phosphorus, Magnesium, Sodium, Potassium, Chloride
  • ➤ Microminerals/Trace minerals (<100 mg/day): Iron, Zinc, Copper, Iodine, Selenium, Chromium, etc.

questions.text: A child presents with progressive muscle weakness, difficulty walking, and frequent falls. Physical examination reveals decreased deep tendon reflexes and foot drop. Recent history includes prolonged hospitalization with total parenteral nutrition without proper supplementation. Which vitamin supplementation would most likely treat this condition? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vitamin E

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Vitamin E deficiency is the correct answer. The clinical presentation suggests vitamin E deficiency neurological syndrome, characterized by:
  • • Progressive spinocerebellar ataxia Peripheral neuropathy with loss of deep tendon reflexes Muscle weakness and foot drop Common in malabsorption states or TPN without adequate supplementation
  • • Progressive spinocerebellar ataxia
  • • Peripheral neuropathy with loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • • Muscle weakness and foot drop
  • • Common in malabsorption states or TPN without adequate supplementation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vitamin D: While vitamin D deficiency can cause muscle weakness, it primarily presents with bone pain, rickets in children, and hypocalcemic symptoms. Neurological symptoms are not predominant.
  • • Option A. Vitamin D:
  • • Option B. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) presents with bleeding manifestations, gum problems, poor wound healing, and fatigue. It doesn't typically cause isolated neurological symptoms.
  • • Option B. Vitamin C:
  • • Option C. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision (night blindness), epithelial integrity, and immune function. Neurological manifestations are not characteristic.
  • • Option C. Vitamin A:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand:
  • ➤ 1. Vitamin E deficiency:
  • ➤ Primarily affects neurological system Common in malabsorption disorders Risk in long-term TPN without supplementation
  • ➤ Primarily affects neurological system
  • ➤ Common in malabsorption disorders
  • ➤ Risk in long-term TPN without supplementation
  • ➤ 2. Clinical manifestations:
  • ➤ Peripheral neuropathy Cerebellar ataxia Progressive muscle weakness Absent reflexes
  • ➤ Peripheral neuropathy
  • ➤ Cerebellar ataxia
  • ➤ Progressive muscle weakness
  • ➤ Absent reflexes
  • ➤ 3. Prevention requires:
  • ➤ Adequate supplementation in TPN Monitoring in malabsorption states Early recognition of neurological symptoms
  • ➤ Adequate supplementation in TPN
  • ➤ Monitoring in malabsorption states
  • ➤ Early recognition of neurological symptoms

  • ➤ Benedict' test - Reducing sugars.
  • ➤ Heat coagulation test - Proteins.

questions.text: The punishment for the death of a patient by spurious drug? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Life imprisonment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, the distribution of spurious drugs that result in death constitutes grievous hurt, warranting severe legal consequences including life imprisonment.

questions.text: True regarding mitochondrial genome?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Maternal inheritance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitochondrial DNA and RNA:
  • ➤ Mitochondrial DNA and RNA:
  • ➤ There is a dichotomy on the mitochondrial metabolism. Some of the mitochondrial protein synthesis is under the control of mitochondrial DNA; but important proteins of the outer membrane of the mitochondria are synthesized under the influence of nuclear DNA. The mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is circular , has about 16,500 nucleotides . The mtDNA has information for synthesis of 2 ribosomal RNAs, 22 tRNAs and 13 proteins . All of them are components of electron transport chain. It has 37 genes that encode 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain (total of 67 i.e., about 20%). However, most of mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and synthesized in the cytoplasm. Maternal inheritance: Since, the mitochondria are inherited cytoplasmically, the mtDNA is inherited from the mother. Mother transmits mtDNA through oocyte. There are hundreds of copies of mtDNA in each cell (nuclear DNA has only 2 copies). Heteroplasmy is defined as the presence of normal and mutant mtDNA in different proportions in different cells. During cell division, mtDNA replicates and they segregate to the daughter cells. If a mutation occurs in mtDNA, the daughter cells may inherit the mutant or normal mtDNA . High mutation rate: 5-10 times that of nuclear DNA Age-related accumulation of mutations in mtDNA may be responsible for age-related decrease in cellular OXPHOS function, and progression of other degenerative diseases. Defects in mitochondrial genome will lead to mitochondrial myopathies .
  • ➤ There is a dichotomy on the mitochondrial metabolism. Some of the mitochondrial protein synthesis is under the control of mitochondrial DNA; but important proteins of the outer membrane of the mitochondria are synthesized under the influence of nuclear DNA.
  • ➤ important proteins of the outer membrane of the mitochondria are synthesized under the influence of nuclear DNA.
  • ➤ The mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is circular , has about 16,500 nucleotides . The mtDNA has information for synthesis of 2 ribosomal RNAs, 22 tRNAs and 13 proteins . All of them are components of electron transport chain. It has 37 genes that encode 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain (total of 67 i.e., about 20%). However, most of mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and synthesized in the cytoplasm.
  • ➤ mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is circular
  • ➤ 16,500 nucleotides
  • ➤ 22 tRNAs
  • ➤ 13 proteins
  • ➤ about 20%).
  • ➤ Maternal inheritance: Since, the mitochondria are inherited cytoplasmically, the mtDNA is inherited from the mother. Mother transmits mtDNA through oocyte.
  • ➤ There are hundreds of copies of mtDNA in each cell (nuclear DNA has only 2 copies).
  • ➤ Heteroplasmy is defined as the presence of normal and mutant mtDNA in different proportions in different cells. During cell division, mtDNA replicates and they segregate to the daughter cells. If a mutation occurs in mtDNA, the daughter cells may inherit the mutant or normal mtDNA .
  • ➤ Heteroplasmy
  • ➤ If a mutation occurs in mtDNA, the daughter cells may inherit the mutant or normal mtDNA
  • ➤ High mutation rate: 5-10 times that of nuclear DNA
  • ➤ 5-10 times
  • ➤ Age-related accumulation of mutations in mtDNA may be responsible for age-related decrease in cellular OXPHOS function, and progression of other degenerative diseases.
  • ➤ Defects in mitochondrial genome will lead to mitochondrial myopathies .
  • ➤ mitochondrial myopathies

questions.text: Vanillyl mandelic acid is excreted in urine in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A Pheochromocytoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The half-life of epinephrine is very short, only 2-5 minutes . Epinephrine is catabolized in tissues, by catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) to metanephrines.
  • ➤ . Epinephrine is catabolized in tissues, by catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) to metanephrines.
  • ➤ It is then acted upon by monoamine oxidase (MAO). MAO will oxidatively deaminate compounds having the amino group attached to the terminal carbon atom. The major end product is 3-hydroxy-4-methoxy mandelic acid or vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA).
  • ➤ The major end product is 3-hydroxy-4-methoxy mandelic acid or vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA).
  • ➤ Normal level of excretion of VMA is 2–6 mg/24 h. It is increased in pheochromocytoma (epinephrine excess) and in neuroblastoma (norepinephrine excess).

questions.text: Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalysed reaction is given by? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction is best represented by Curve A, which shows the formation of a transition state and the reduction in activation energy, leading to the production of the final product.

questions.text: Congenital lactic acidosis is due to the defect of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pyruvate dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is a key cause of congenital lactic acidosis, as it prevents the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, leading to an accumulation of lactic acid.

questions.text: For patients with coronary artery disease, which fatty acid consumption should be LIMITED for prevention of disease progression? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Saturated fatty acids

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Saturated fatty acids should be limited in patients with coronary artery disease as they increase LDL cholesterol levels and promote atherosclerosis. High intake of saturated fats contributes to plaque formation in coronary arteries and increases cardiovascular risk. Guidelines recommend limiting saturated fat intake to less than 7% of total daily calories for patients with coronary artery disease.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Omega 3 FA: Omega-3 fatty acids are beneficial for cardiovascular health. They reduce inflammation, lower triglycerides, and have mild anticoagulant properties. Rather than being limited, their intake should be encouraged.
  • • Option B. Omega 3 FA:
  • • Option C. Omega 6 FA: While maintaining a proper omega-6 to omega-3 ratio is important, omega-6 fatty acids are essential fatty acids. When consumed in moderation as part of a balanced diet, they contribute to normal growth and development.
  • • Option C. Omega 6 FA:
  • • Option D. Omega 9 FA: Omega-9 fatty acids, found in olive oil, are heart-healthy monounsaturated fats. They help reduce LDL cholesterol while maintaining HDL levels and don't need to be limited.
  • • Option D. Omega 9 FA:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In coronary artery disease prevention, the focus should be on limiting saturated fatty acid intake while encouraging consumption of healthier fats like omega-3, appropriate amounts of omega-6, and omega-9 fatty acids. Understanding which fats to limit versus increase is crucial for proper dietary management of cardiovascular disease

questions.text: Cause of death in the position shown in the image below is: ( AIIMS Nov 2017)

  • ➤ 2. Compression of neck
  • ➤ 2. Compression of neck
  • ➤ Hanging – force is body weight / body is suspended Strangulation – force is anything other than body weight / no suspension.
  • ➤ Hanging – force is body weight / body is suspended
  • ➤ Strangulation – force is anything other than body weight / no suspension.

questions.text: Amongst the poisons given below, which poison can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Arsenic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arsenic can be found in skeletal remains for several years after death due to its strong binding to the bone matrix and slow release over time.

questions.text: Given the image showing Apo B protein synthesis, where does RNA editing of the B-100 mRNA occur to produce Apo B-48? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intestine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • RNA editing of Apo B mRNA occurs specifically in the intestine, where a cytidine deaminase enzyme converts a specific cytidine (C) to uridine (U) in the mRNA. This creates a premature stop codon, resulting in the production of the shorter Apo B-48 protein. This tissue-specific editing does not occur in the liver, where the unedited mRNA produces full-length Apo B-100.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Liver: In the liver, no RNA editing occurs, allowing the full translation of the mRNA to produce Apo B-100. The editing machinery is not active in hepatic tissue.
  • • Option A. Liver:
  • • Option C. Both liver and intestine: RNA editing of Apo B mRNA is tissue-specific and occurs only in the intestine, not in both organs. If editing occurred in both tissues, Apo B-100 would not be produced.
  • • Option C. Both liver and intestine:
  • • Option D. Neither liver nor intestine: This is incorrect as RNA editing definitely occurs in intestinal cells, where the specific cytidine deaminase is expressed and active.
  • • Option D. Neither liver nor intestine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding tissue-specific RNA editing is crucial for comprehending how one gene can produce two different proteins in different tissues. In this case, intestine-specific RNA editing creates Apo B-48, while the absence of editing in the liver allows production of full-length Apo B-100

questions.text: The enzyme that is common for both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Phosphoglycerate kinase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phosphoglycerate kinase is a common enzyme in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, catalyzing a reversible reaction that interconverts 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate and 3-phosphoglycerate.
  • ➤ Other reversible steps of glycolysis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:
  • ➤ Other reversible steps of glycolysis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:
  • ➤ Phosphoglycerate mutase Glyceraldehyde phosphate dehydrogenase Triose phosphate isomerase Aldolase Phosphohexose isomerase
  • ➤ Phosphoglycerate mutase
  • ➤ Glyceraldehyde phosphate dehydrogenase
  • ➤ Triose phosphate isomerase
  • ➤ Aldolase
  • ➤ Phosphohexose isomerase

questions.text: You are working as a casualty medical officer. A 16-year-old girl is brought to the casualty by her parents after alleged sexual assault, the girl refuses physical examination. Which of the following would you do? Start treatment for STD and pregnancy Inform the police Record refusal of consent Take vaginal samples Start medical examination
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 1, 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ As the girl is under 18 years of age, as per POCSO (The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) act 2012, the medical practitioner should start treatment for STI & pregnancy, inform the police and record the refusal of consent for examination

questions.text: Which of the following is the bleeding vessel in extradural hemorrhage? (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Bridging veins leading to bleeding in epidural space

options.label: C
options.text: Circle of Willis leading to bleeding in Subarachnoid space

options.label: D
options.text: Anterior cerebral artery leading to bleeding in subdural space

questions.correct_answer: A. Middle meningeal artery leading to bleeding in epidural space
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Middle meningeal artery leading to bleeding in epidural space

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Key points:
  • ➤ Key points:
  • ➤ Subdural Hematoma (SDH) : Typically caused by trauma, specifically related to tearing of bridging veins. Epidural Hematoma (EDH) : Always due to trauma and specifically linked to arterial damage, often involving the middle meningeal artery, a branch of the internal maxillary artery. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH) : Mostly associated with trauma, with bridging veins being the common source. However, SAH can also be non-traumatic, often resulting from rupture of berry aneurysms.
  • ➤ Subdural Hematoma (SDH) : Typically caused by trauma, specifically related to tearing of bridging veins.
  • ➤ Subdural Hematoma (SDH)
  • ➤ Epidural Hematoma (EDH) : Always due to trauma and specifically linked to arterial damage, often involving the middle meningeal artery, a branch of the internal maxillary artery.
  • ➤ Epidural Hematoma (EDH)
  • ➤ Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH) : Mostly associated with trauma, with bridging veins being the common source. However, SAH can also be non-traumatic, often resulting from rupture of berry aneurysms.
  • ➤ Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH)

questions.text: Which micronutrient deficiency causes anemia, bleeding gums, and white line of Frenkel on X-ray? (NEET PG 2024)

  • • Mechanism: Corrosive
  • • Mechanism:
  • • Explanation: Potassium carbonate is an alkali that has a corrosive action on tissues, causing chemical burns upon contact.
  • • Explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding non-competitive inhibition? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.correct_answer: B. Constant Km and decreased Vmax
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Constant Km and decreased Vmax

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Noncompetitive inhibition has constant Km and decreased Vmax.
  • • More complex noncompetitive inhibition occurs when binding of the inhibitor does affect the apparent affinity of the enzyme for substrate, causing the lines to intercept in either the third or fourth quadrants of a double-reciprocal plot.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the image given below? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with a case of electrical burns

questions.correct_answer: B. Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marbling, a postmortem change characterized by greenish-black lines on the skin, is due to the accumulation and formation of sulph-meth-hemoglobin during putrefaction.

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hypothermia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paradoxical undressing occurs in hypothermia victims who, despite experiencing extremely low temperatures, remove their clothing due to a sudden and misleading sensation of warmth.
